    Head J (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [18th March, 1996],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head J of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon].

    Question again proposed.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Yuhua): Sir, in October 1994, the Minister for Community Development released the Report of the Inter-Ministry Committee on Juvenile Delinquency, Dysfunctional Families and Drug Abuse. The recommendations were wide-ranging and aimed to put in place further measures to address the needs of

Column: 1544

dysfunctional families and juvenile delinquents. Recent police figures show that the number of juveniles arrested went up from 1,200 in 1990 to 2,500 last year. With the recent rise in juvenile crimes and offences, the recommendations are timely and crucial.

    I would also like to bring to the attention of the House of a group of youths who had failed in their PSLE examinations. If they are forced to study, the absenteeism rate may be high because they have no interest in their studies. They cannot join ITE for technical training because they are under age. I would like to ask the Minister whether there is any programme specially designed for this group of youths to counsel and guide them so that they will not waste their time hanging around shopping centres or roaming around.

    I would also like to ask the Minister about the Report of the IMC. Could the Minister update us on its progress?

    The other area that I would like to touch on is Singapore Family Values. Since 1994, when the Ministry of Community Development launched the Singapore Family Values (SFV), much has been said about the importance of preserving family values in our society. The focus is on the family because it is one of the most important factors underpinning the progress of Singapore. We see the SFV being promoted in schools, buses, taxi-cabs, MRT stations, TV, radio and several publications and mass events. Many members of the public praise the programme, especially over TCS. However, lately, the programme has stopped. I would like to urge that this effort deserves praise and should be encouraged and supported. I would like to ask the Minister to let us know how much has been spent, whether he sees a need to sustain or, better still, expand the promotion of SFV and whether the $1 million for five years is sufficient.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Bedok GRC): Sir, I wish to address the issues of dysfunctional families and juvenile delinquency. First, I would like to congratulate the authors on a very thorough and frank report.

Column: 1545



    Sir, the Report of the Inter-Ministry Committee has shown that divorces doubled between 1980 and 1990. Divorces were 0.71 per 1,000 residents in 1980 and rose to 1.34 per 1,000 residents. Although this figure, termed the crude divorce rate, is much lower than the 4.7 in the US and 2.9 in the UK in 1990, there is no room for complacency.

    Sir, we all accept that the family is the basic building block of our society. The consequences of marital failure affect also the children. I note the many measures recommended by the Committee. I, however, urge the MCD to give more resources to the family service centres, managed by the voluntary organisations, so that they can be more effective in doing their job rather than spending the majority of their time on fund-raising.

    Next, I would like to focus on the preventive aspects. Many religious groups already make it compulsory that the couple whose marriage is to be solemnised by their religious leader has to attend some formal instruction or classes before the marriage is solemnised. I believe that the Registry of Marriages should now make it compulsory for every Singaporean who wants to be married to attend a similar course and accredited pre-marital counselling courses organised by other agencies. The marriage certificate carries with it far greater responsibility than a driving licence or a COE.

    On community support groups (CSGs), I understand that the Residents' Committees (RCs) are being asked to form CSGs to address many of the problems mentioned in this report. Is the MCD going to provide training and guidance to these CSGs? How will they be funded? I believe that the formation of CSGs is a step in the right direction, but to be effective, the volunteers must be given the tools to do their job.

    Sir, the explosive problem of juvenile delinquency (or young offenders) needs to be addressed very seriously and urgently. Juvenile delinquents (aged 7 - 16 years) who took to crime doubled between 1980

Column: 1546

and 1990. The figure rose another 74.4% between 1990 and 1994. The number of female offenders rose 413% from 1984 to 1993.

    Sir, the problem is serious enough now for the MCD to form a team solely dedicated to tackling this problem. Mobilising other agencies, such as the family service centres and other voluntary groups and agencies (eg, the Police and the People's Association) should be supplementary to the main effort. Will the Minister comment on this?

    To me, the whole of Singapore's society, workforce, social and economic progress will be jeopardised if this problem is not given the highest of priority, not to mention the waste of the individual's life. Ad-hoc programmes and the mobilisation of existing resources will not be able to give the focused attention and additional resources that this important problem requires.

    Sir, the Inter-Ministry Committee's Report has identified the high-risk cases and has made many recommendations for tackling this problem. Here I would like to bring up the issue of "EQ" or emotional intelligence or competence and juvenile delinquency. If we take the experience in the US, we will be even more motivated to do more and now. In 1990, compared to the previous two decades, the US saw the highest juvenile arrest rate for violent crimes ever; teen arrests for forcible rape had doubled; teen murder rates quadrupled; suicide rate for teenagers tripled; and murders of children under the age of 14 tripled.

    American experts have pointed out that the dropping levels of "emotional competence" seem to have a very direct bearing on these alarming statistics. The whole issue of "EQ" or emotional intelligence or emotional competence in our teenagers needs to be addressed. A Cornell University study did an international comparison of children's well-being. Its conclusion:

    'In the absence of good support systems, external stresses have become so great that even strong families are falling apart. The hecticness, instability, and inconsistency of daily family life are rampant in all

Column: 1547

segments of our society, including the well-educated and well-to-do. What is at stake is nothing less than the next generation ...'.

    Sir, in the US, the profile has also been studied, and the conclusion is that the "pathway to violence and criminality starts with children who are aggressive and hard to handle in first and second grades [ie, ages 7 - 8 years]." Is there hope for these children? Some success has been attained. Timely help can change attitudes and help aggressive kids learn to control anti-social behaviour before it leads them to more serious trouble. One such programme at Duke University worked with anger-ridden grade-school trouble makers. They were put through sessions for 40 minutes, twice a week, for 6-12 weeks. They benefitted, and in a controlled study, it was found that those going through the course became "much less disruptive in class, had more positive feelings about themselves, and were less likely to drink or take drugs. And, the longer they had been in the programme, the less aggressive they were as teenagers."

    Sir, my purpose in bringing up this issue of "EQ" is to highlight that early intervention and assistance can help the individual and society. Our Prime Minister referred to this on 22nd December 1995 when he said, "Character determines whether a person succeeds in life or not. High IQ alone is not enough." He then referred to the book by Daniel Goleman entitled "Emotional Intelligence - Why It Can Matter More Than IQ" and the Straits Times had this to report about the Prime Minister:

    `He had not heard of the term "Emotional Intelligence" when he was at school, he said, but on looking back, he realised that he had absorbed "a heavy dose of emotional intelligence" at RI. "It built my character. It gave me the emotional gravitas to lead."'.

    Sir, the MCD needs to initiate such a programme, probably in conjunction with the Ministry of Education, Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Home Affairs. Special attention needs to be given to the problem of the girls. The 400% rise in female juvenile delinquents deserves special attention.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin ( Nominated Member): Sir, the Inter-Ministry Committee under the

Column: 1548

chairmanship of the Minister came out with a commendable report. Would the Minister be good enough to tell the House:

    (1) What recommendations of this report have already been implemented or are in the process of being implemented; and

    (2) What are the plans for the other recommendations that have not begun the process of implementation.

    In particular, could the Minister please elaborate on these four issues:

    (i) In the IMC Report, the Committee suggests that MCD conducts studies to determine the profile of lower-income families in need of financial assistance. Has this study commenced?

    (ii) The Committee also recommends that a separate centre should be set up by MCD to rehabilitate young drug addicts who should be kept apart from older and more hardened drug addicts. What plans are under way for this?

    (iii) There is a recommendation to create a central database on young offenders to facilitate planning and research. Is the Ministry of Community Development or the Ministry of Home Affairs doing this?

    (iv) It is stated in the Report that MCD will conduct a major study into the state of the Singapore families soon and this study will look at both healthy families and those in distress. Has this study begun? Would the Minister please give us some assurance that all these recommendations are under way or soon will be?

     Mr Zulkifli bin Mohammed (Jalan Besar GRC)( In Malay): Sir, in the last few years, Singapore has seen a new unwelcome trend, ie, the number of juvenile offenders has increased. In 1990, the number was 1,005 but this has increased to 1,300 this year. Last year, it had jumped to 2,009. This is a great increase, almost 115% within a period of five years. The picture is more shocking when we take into consideration the report by the police recently that for 1995, 10% of the juveniles and the youths who were arrested are those

Column: 1549

between 7 and 15 years old and the female juveniles who had been arrested are also increasing.
12.45 pm

    Secondly, the report also shows that the crimes committed by them are becoming more serious. For instance, murder and rioting. As a small country with limited talent, we should be anxious about the long-term effect of these juvenile offenders because in future, they will become criminals. If we do not pay particular attention to this problem now, it will affect the future generation. The reasons why they are involved in crimes have been identified by the Inter-Ministry Committee on Dysfunctional Families, Drug Abuse and Juvenile Delinquency.

    Sir, what we have acknowledged in Singapore is that the community should nurture strong family values as a long-term and effective solution to handle this problem. To achieve this objective, a consolidated approach among the Government Ministries and agencies should be stepped up. In this respect, I would like to hear from the Minister what are the recommendations of the Inter-Ministry Committee that have been implemented and what further measures will be taken to reduce the number of offences.

     The Chairman: Mr Shanmugam is not here. Dr Soin, you can take your two topics together.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Sir, my first cut is on before-and-after school care. The IMC report concluded that and I quote:

    `Children who are left to fend for themselves while their parents are at work are more likely to fall into bad company. The Committee proposes that before-and-after school care services be provided for these children and, where possible, they should be based in school and run by voluntary groups.' In another part of the report, the IMC states that before-and-after school care services should be kept affordable. It is to be commended that MCD is already putting this recommendation into practice and is offering VWOs 80% of development

Column: 1550

expenditure and 50% of running costs for developing and operating before-and-after school care.

    However, I feel that the Ministry must take on a much bigger role in before-and-after school care service besides the financing help. The Ministry is doing a good job in fulfilling this role in the provision of child care services. Some of the areas that require to be undertaken by the MCD in the case of before-and-after school care are:

    (1) to formulate basic rules and regulations on the setting up of before-and-after school care;

    (2) to define the roles and responsibilities of the providers of before-and-after school care and the minimum qualifications required of these providers;

    (3) to set a standarised curriculum to ensure minimum standards and consistency and uniformity in the delivery of the programme and this may have to be done in conjunction with the Ministry of Education;

    (4) to set guidelines on the fees chargeable and to ensure these fees remain affordable to children from lower income families - it might be necessary for the Government to give a subsidy to before-and-after school care just like it does for child care; and

    (5) to take on the role of a consultant to provide consultant expertise to service providers.

    In the matter of child care, as I have said, MCD is fulfilling these roles. Would the Minister consider the suggestion that his Ministry assume the same responsibilities in the case of before-and-after school care? This role of MCD is important as, besides physical custodial care, before-and-after school care will also impact on the child's moral and intellectual development. I would therefore urge the Minister to ensure that his Ministry take on a proactive and regulatory approach to the setting up and implementation of before-and-after school care facilities.

Column: 1551



    My next cut, Sir, is on mandatory reporting of child abuse. Presently, there is no law requiring mandatory reporting of child abuse and neglect in Singapore. Data from a survey done in 1995 by the Children's Society indicate that there may be a high rate of under-reporting, perhaps as high as 80%. So the true incident rate is likely to be higher than what is officially reported. Would the Minister initiate a move to consider mandatory reporting of cases of child abuse and neglect handled by his Ministry, Ministry of Home Affairs, Ministry of Health and VWOs?

    The mandatory reporting should be done to the MCD who could then initiate investigations by social workers and the Child Welfare Section and take the necessary action. Here, it would be very relevant to quote the Minister himself before he assumed his Ministerial post and this is what he said in this House, in January 1993, during the Second Reading of the Children and Young Persons Bill, and I quote [Hansard, Vol. 60, col. 453]:

    `I would like to say a few words about mandatory reporting by medical practitioners to the Protector of Children of cases of possible physical or emotional injury of children under their medical examination. I can understand the difficulties of enforcing such a system - the need for it in the local context and the possibility of such a system discouraging parents or guardians from seeking treatment for abused children. But this could at least reveal more cases which would otherwise be lost or hidden. So I do hope that the Ministry of Community Development and the Ministry of Health would not drop this subject altogether for the earlier mentioned reasons, but would continue to monitor the situation to see whether such an option need to be implemented here in future.'

    If this view was held by the Minister three years ago, then I am sure that he will be supportive of the suggestion of mandatory reporting of child abuse and neglect brought to the attention of VWOs, his Ministry, Ministry of Health and Ministry of Home Affairs. And finally, I would like the Minister to consider the setting up of a central registry of child abuse in addition to mandatory reporting.

     The Chairman: Mrs Yu-Foo, you can take your two subjects together.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon: Sir, when we enter into the 21st century, we should focus on the problems of an aging population. At present, there are more and

Column: 1552

more nuclear families. Many young couples prefer to stay on their own. There will be more and more elderly parents who live on their own. This number will increase significantly and may pose social problems in the future.

    As the family size is getting smaller, my concern is when the young couples and children are working during the day, who will take care of the elderly when they need assistance?

    I see that there is a need for a community networking support system as well as close coordination between MCD and other relevant Ministries to ensure a more coordinated approach to service delivery. Are there any efforts made to mobilise grassroots, voluntary organisations and senior citizens' clubs as well as individuals, such as the well-elderly to give voluntary service to the elderly in need like home visits and to look after the basic needs of the elderly? And I would also like to ask the Minister whether the Ministry will set up more day care centres for the elderly.

    Sir, in November 1995, Parliament passed the Maintenance of Parents Bill. I am pleased that in passing the Bill, the idea of a Tribunal received very favourable support from Members of this House. In passing the Bill, I was pleased that MCD has found an appropriate set-up which would allow for a more mediatory approach to a rather sensitive family matter. MCD has taken the feedback from the public well and incorporated a tribunal which will put in place a legal mechanism to help parents who need help to seek maintenance from their children while enabling the parties involved to sort out their problems in a less austere atmosphere of a court. More importantly, there is room for mediation and counselling, if necessary.

    I understand that a Tribunal for the maintenance of parents will be set up soon. I would like to ask the Minister on the application and administration procedures of the Act and what sort of mechanism MCD has set up to implement the Act.

     Mr Choo Wee Khiang (Jalan Besar GRC)( In Mandarin): Sir, I often see handicapped

Column: 1553

and elderly people on wheel chairs moving about in the streets. However, I notice that most of our buildings and roads are not user-friendly to people on wheel chairs. On one occasion, I saw a person on a wheel chair trying to cross the junction of New Bridge Road and Upper Cross Street with great difficulty. There was no ramp on the curb of the road. So when this person came down from the curb, he almost fell off from his wheel chair. I would like to ask the Minister whether he has any long-term plan to provide better user-friendly facilities to facilitate the movement of handicapped and elderly people.

    I feel that the Ministry of Community Development should set up a special planning committee comprising officers from the various Government Ministries and statutory boards, especially the LTA, Ministry of Health and MND, to look into the question of coordinating the activities of the various Government agencies in planning public facilities, with special consideration for the needs of elderly and handicapped people. At the moment, I understand that the Building Control Division, under the Ministry of National Development, stipulates the provision of certain facilities to be provided in the new towns for the benefit of the elderly and handicapped people. But I feel that this is not enough. I hope that the Minister can consider setting up a special planning committee to provide overall planning for the provision of user-friendly facilities for the handicapped and elderly people.

    The second point I wish to bring up is on the question of work for the handicapped and elderly people. I would like to ask MCD whether there is any special agency to look after the employment needs of these people for the maintenance of their livelihood. Of course, the Ministry of Labour has a special agency to help the handicapped people to look for jobs. But elderly people and handicapped people have different employment needs. So I would like to ask the Minister for Community Development what role is his Ministry playing in this respect.

Column: 1554



    Next, on the question of respect for the aged. Filial piety and respect for the aged are the traditional virtues of Singaporeans. Parents brought up and cared for their children. Their contribution is very great, and it is because of this contribution that we have the Singapore of today. Family cohesiveness, respect for the aged and filial piety are very important aspects of our social lives. Just imagine, Sir, if we are a society that does not pay attention to filial piety and have no respect for the elderly, then parents will be discarded by their children. Our social order will be undermined, and this will lead to a vicious cycle which will undermine our social cohesion.

    Sir, this will be a terrible situation. So I hope that we should start from the fundamental, ie, to respect the aged. I would suggest that the present "Senior Citizens' Week" be renamed as "Respect for the Elderly Week", so that the senior citizens will feel the respect and the care given to them. More importantly, we can use the Respect for the Elderly Week to encourage young people to pay respect to the aged.
1.00 pm

     Mr R. Sinnakaruppan (Kampong Glam GRC): Sir, the information technology (IT) era has opened up a whole new world of opportunities and possibilities that would facilitate the way we work and the way we live. One special group of people who would benefit tremendously from IT are the handicapped. I strongly believe that initiating them into IT is one of the most effective ways to integrate them into the mainstream of life. IT would help to liberate all forms of physical limitations.

    Sir, I recently officiated at the opening of the first computer centre for the handicapped initiated by the Handicaps Welfare Association. With the help of one of the polytechnics and the private sector, they have integrated innovative handicap-friendly input devices for the handicapped, so that even the paralysed can surf the Internet and write letters using word processor software. One of these beneficiaries told me and I quote:

Column: 1555



    `This project has taken the disillusion and boredom out of my life, and has added a new dimension and meaning to my existence. I can even contribute to the economy instead of just being a burden or a beneficiary.' I am very touched by what IT has done to his life.

    With the advent of virtual organisations where people need not work under one roof, but from their homes through the PC, it will now be possible to enable and increase the participation of the disabled in our workforce. This would be a valued contribution from them, especially in our tight labour market. Employers must come forward to seize this mutually beneficial arrangement.

    I would also like to strongly urge the Government to pay more attention to the promotion of IT for the handicapped by giving funds and facilities to initiate the handicapped to IT. Prof. Stephen Hawking, a Nobel Prize winner and a Mathematics professor from Cambridge University, is a shining example of how the handicapped can contribute to society at large. So I urge the Minister to do more for the handicapped in Singapore. And I join my colleague, Mr Choo Wee Khiang, in asking for a committee to be formed, not just for the facilities, but also to try and work with the Ministry of Labour to identify new job opportunities, particularly in the area of IT, for the handicapped in Singapore.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Sir, my subject is on the employment of the disabled.

    From available statistics, it appears that there are only 283 disabled persons employed by the various Government institutions and statutory boards. This number, when taken as a percentage of total Government employees, is insignificant and falls far below ideal expectations. The question that comes to mind is: why is there such a low employment rate of disabled persons in the public sector? Should the Government not lead by example, by opening up employment opportunities to the disabled and removing as many obstacles as possible to gainful employment?

    Another issue in addressing the problem of unemployment of the disabled is the

Column: 1556

availability of data. Since the last survey on the employment of disabled persons was carried out in 1984, I understand there has been no similar compilation of data. I would like to suggest that the Ministry of Community Development takes on the major ownership of this challenge of addressing the needs and aspirations of the disabled for employment. And I would like to join my colleagues, Mr Choo and Mr Sinnakaruppan, in asking for the setting up of a high level committee. In particular, I would like to suggest a few areas that the Ministry can address:

    (1) Documentation of data of the disabled people - to establish a profile of the general situation of disabled people and assist them in meeting their needs.

    (2) Match-making role, ie, source employment opportunities and allocate jobs to the disabled by getting them in touch with their employers. This can be done in collaboration with VWOs who are already working in this area, eg, Bizlink.

    (3) MCD can play an active role in ensuring that relevant VWOs, which provide training services to the disabled, follow up with the latter's vocational needs. And MCD can also educate other Ministries in dispelling the myths about the employment of disabled people which may be present.

    I would therefore like to urge the Minister to ensure that his Ministry look into these areas so that the disabled would be less advantaged and marginalised in terms of employment.

     Mr Choo Wee Khiang( In Mandarin): Sir, at the moment, besides the Singapore Indoor Stadium, we also have several regional mini indoor stadiums. Since the opening of the Singapore Indoor Stadium, many sports, cultural and entertainment activities have been carried out there. Spectators who attend these functions at this beautiful stadium find it comfortable and enjoyable. Apart from the contents of these programmes and activities, more importantly, the Indoor Stadium has very good, comprehensive and state-of-the-art facilities and equipment.

    But if we look at the regional mini indoor stadiums, I think they are a far cry from the Singapore Indoor Stadium. For

Column: 1557
